job_title: Health Informatics Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: The ADA has a great, welcoming culture and strives for diversity and inclusion of people of all backgrounds. It is also a culture that takes great pride in its mission and its service to the dental profession and their patients
cons: The governance structure is cumbersome and perhaps a little outdated

job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Chicago, IL
pros: People are nice and helpful.

review_title: Good Work as well as Work Life Balance
job_title: Manager, Content Delivery in Chicago, IL
pros: Awesome CEO, in Dr. O'Loughlin; work life balance; talented staff and employees.
cons: Can't think of any right now.

pros: Lots of paid time off
cons: Not really well run from a mgmt perspective

pros: Those who stay for a long time can build up a huge amount of annual vacation time. There are some decent departments and some really  great people to work with.
cons:
"Leadership" lacks leadership skills. Many people in very high positions are corrupt or abusive, or are clueless about the actual work needing to be done. There are zero repercussions for abuses by management, especially in HR. There is little recognition for hard workers, and many employees who have been around for years or even decades are allowed to slide by or get promoted without doing much or attempting to update their skills or meet the basic requirements of their positions, forcing others to constantly pick up the slack.

Work/life balance varies considerably depending on department. Some departments cruise out the door by 4-4:30 every day and/or are able to set up great work-from-home schedules. Other departments are constantly overworked up to 80+ hours a week, rarely allowed to work remotely, and expected to answer texts and emails from managers at all hours of the night and weekends.

review_title: It's a good place to work overall. Great benefits, including a pension, and salaries are higher than most.
pros: Staff works hard to promote the value of good dental health to the public and please ADA members. Members are appreciative of the staff's hard work. It's a national organization so everybody knows the ADA. The perks are great and the Gold Coast location is awesome. Staff members are friendly and are always willing to help their colleagues get the job done. Employees are given opportunities to grow their skills.
cons: Membership numbers are falling so staff is working so hard to stop the decline that they are missing out on opportunities to educate the public about the value of good dental health. Too much red tape to actually facilitate change. Some directors are lazy and unqualified so they push work off on overworked managers yet don't give them the proper guidance they need to be successful. Executives play favorites with managerial staff so other staff members are left out. Executives always talk about strategy yet the programs they launch have no strategic focus.

pros: Great people, innovative technology, strong leadership, many perks beyond traditional benefits
cons: So many meetings that can interfere with productivity

review_title: Best place to work! They care about their employees.
pros: Awesome culture and work-life balance, D & I focused, cares about employees, casual work environment with the ability to work from home (pre-covid19), forward thinking and innovative, diversed senior and management teams, 37.5 hour work week with summer hours, excellent benefits, including pension, summer hours and pet insurance, collaborative work environment.... I can go on and on. I love working at the ADA and can't see myself working any place else. This is the first place that values the ideas and contributions of everyone, from all different levels and titles. A previous review said the raises were 2%, not true. My raises have been more than that, so I'm guessing that person was underperforming. Also, my bonuses have been way more than $500, so that person, again, was obviously underperforming. They had so many negative things to say, but they still work there. Strange.
cons: Can't really "climb the ladder." Some managers want to meet all the time when it could've been just a simple phone call or email. The cafeteria is not the best and is over priced. These are so minor compared to the benefits of working at the ADA.

pros:
- Leadership that genuinely cares about making the ADA a good place to work (Dr. O'Loughlin in particular, the Executive Director, is a great role model)
- Ability to work from home
- Casual dress code
- Open communication
- Being a part of a non-profit that is well-established 
- Room for advancement for those who excel
cons:
- Space for meetings is limited. It's hard to find a place to talk with coworkers about projects without the entire office overhearing. Meeting rooms are often booked far in advance. 
- The dental coverage is flexible (you can go anywhere you want), but not substantial. I need ~$10,000 in dental work done, but am going without because it would require using my entire savings.

pros: You can work amidst friendly and qualified employees who love their jobs. Great retirement package.
cons: Major disconnect between management and employees.  Limited diversity. Communication is at an all time low.  Employees discover major decisions on the tail end.  Dysfunctional work environment(s).  Uneven hierarchy. Management is only concerned with their own successes and not the success and growth of the worker bees who work tirelessly for this member organization.  Benefits are sketchy. The dental plan is horrible!

review_title: Not a lifetime job, but a solid workplace
pros: Stable 37.5 hour work week that does not require overtime.  Fair compensation and PTO.  Very good (though somewhat pricey) health insurance and 100% reimbursement for dental care up to annual cap, graduated reimbursement after that.  New Executive Director is interested in what the employees have to say, is making efforts to foster a community atmosphere.
cons: Some of the management/Senior Management are not involved with their employees, do not have any understanding or appreciation for the quantity and quality of work that is done.  Dentistry is a very political profession, and employees get caught up in the politics.  Work schedule is not flexible.

pros: Great salary. Education and resources available at your fingertips. A super supportive environment and friendly staff. Casual but polished atmosphere. A fiercely smart and passionate staff (at least the department I work in). I couldn't have asked for a better team to work with. Everyone wants to see you succeed here. Most people stay here long-term (which you don't find these days) --and that's because the organization's management pours into its employees. Employee team-building events and socials are a ton of fun. Excellent work/life balance. I could go on forever... simply put, ADA rocks!
cons: Nothing as of yet. So far, so good.

pros: Awesome benefits like flexible work options (work-from-home), lots of PTO, option to wear jeans every day if you want, lots of free food (in my department at least), great pay, not to mention the CEO is an amazing person. I love my coworkers and our laptops are super nice. My boss is the best!
cons: The commute from the suburbs can be difficult since the ADA building is a little far from the train station. There are a lot of touchy politics (regarding volunteers and members) that are really frustrating to deal with sometimes.

pros: Dr. O is the absolute best Executive Director - I feel proud to work for an organization under her leadership. I love that we can work from home and wear jeans, and the pay exceeds most others in the industry. Great benefits too! I love my boss and coworkers. There are lost of opportunities for professional development and pathways to move up.
cons: Long commute from the suburbs

review_title: Smart People, Good Work, Collaborative Teams
job_title: Manager, Content Delivery in Chicago, IL
pros: Great work-life balance. Pay is commensurate with skills. Career development courses are available at all levels. The work they do is important for consumers & dentists.
cons: There aren't more opportunities open at the ADA. I'm glad I have my position, given the limited positions. Can't say enough about the ADA, so much so, this is my "con."

review_title: great place if you just want a place to work
pros: decent salary,  great location on michigan ave
cons: politics within the organization as well as volunteers, red tape to get simple project done, difficult systems to work in, expensive benefits

review_title: Nice people, challenging work, non-profit...political structure similar to AMA.

pros: If interested in staying has excellent retirement package.
cons: Hires college graduates that last only 90 days, need to hire more experienced employees who are interested in staying.

pros: It's a great company to work for and the pay is standard.
cons: They don't promote within or even try to match you up to a simular position

pros: Great benefits package, compensation, and work/life balance.

pros: Diverse and well-qualified employees who take pride in their interesting, purposeful work. Good benefits.
